task: Write a clear, motivating call to action for the end of the newsletter. The CTA should always promote the Microsoft 365 Productivity Masterclass. It must appear in a P.S. and be naturally connected to the topic of the newsletter (e.g. Teams, Outlook, OneNote).
task_goal: Help the reader see the Masterclass as the next logical step to build on what they just learned. Make the CTA short, calm, and topic-specific—framed as a helpful next step, not a sales pitch.
example: P.S. Want to organize your Outlook in a way that actually works? The Microsoft 365 Productivity Masterclass gives you the full setup—calendar, email triage, and task capture, all streamlined. [Join here →]

newsletter.newsletter_cta: A single P.S. paragraph (1–2 short sentences max), informal and clear, ending with the link to the Microsoft 365 Productivity Masterclass

instructions: Write the CTA as a P.S. at the end of the newsletter
Connect the call to action to the tool or topic discussed (if identifiable)
Make the course feel like the next logical step—not a generic promotion
Use a calm, confident, and conversational tone
Avoid hype, urgency tricks, or filler phrases
Keep it to 1–2 sentences max and end with the course link
